posts.cooked:
The text is:

Recently my team got a bunch of new CTRE products and we are faced with the options of writing our own code or using the swerve generator in phoenix tuner. What are the pros and cons of each and which is recommended for my team to use?

```text recently my team got a bunch of new ctre products and we are faced with the options of writing our own code or using the swerve generator in phoenix tuner what are the pros and cons of each and which is recommended for my team to use ```

posts.name: Guy
posts.cooked: Without getting into specific details: If you have done swerve before and have specific needs or ideas on what you need from the code, custom code. Otherwise, CTRE Swerve.
Can you provide some examples of the specific needs I would require beyond what CTRE Swerve offers?

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
If you're interested in trying out different physics models for swerve or unique control systems, it might not be your best path, but if you're involved in some intense research, there doesn't seem to be much against it. However, if you're doing such work but aren't fully confident in your software expertise, you might be better off reallocating your time.

On the other hand, I believe there's value in revisiting either the "legacy" version of the codebase or frameworks like YAGSL to explore and understand what's been done and how it works.

posts.name: Owen
posts.cooked: We used the Cross The Road Electronics generator for our off-season and it is definitely easier and faster than writing custom code, especially if you don’t have experience with Swerve code.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: The benefits of a custom implementation may not be achievable this season due to the current timing (mid November!). If custom swerve code is still of interest, consider tackling it in 2026 during the off-season.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: We wrote our own swerve code and have recently rewritten it to fix some bugs. We are happy with our own custom code because we do not like to use things as a black box. We did not attempt to utilize the CTRE swerve, as it did not exist when we developed our initial solution, and we have already committed to our custom approach.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development

posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. 

The text is: 

The text contains HTML tags and other elements that need to be removed. Here is the cleaned version:

and we have already committed to our custom solution.

I would try to get out of that mindset, frc code is very easy to blow away and recreate from the ground up.

The CTRE abbreviation code will always be better than custom code because it's maintained and optimized by CTRE for CTRE hardware. You can recreate it but maintaining it including new features while building out a robot program during build season is probably not feasible as very few teams can do so effectively.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: We don’t have any problems maintaining things like this. This year, we’ve added new features and fixed bugs. I’m unsure about its sustainability in the future because two people handle it—keeping it updated (me and another senior member). However, many teams find it unsustainable.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Beyond that, CTRE employees have far more expertise and knowledge of how their hardware works than 99.9% of the teams out there. As a result, the CTRE code is almost always going to out-perform team solutions, save a few rare examples. As far as black boxes go, it doesn’t have to be. While most teams rely on on-motor motion and velocity control, it’s very easy to teach the basic theory so the team members know what they’re doing. The same goes for swerve. Ether’s original papers and Excel can be used to teach all the theory. You can spend the rest of your time addressing the unique facets of the game challenge, rather than worrying about if you’re going to move around the field effectively. But - as always - everyone approaches this differently. What works for one team might not be the way you want to go.

posts.name: Sean Handel
posts.cooked: I agree with the comments that if you are starting out with Swerve drive, using CTRE version is going to be helpful. And since it’s late in the year, it’s even less likely that you could get a custom version working as well as what they auto-generate. Consider doing custom version as an offseason project over the summer.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked:
A custom setpoint generator calculates the robot’s linear and angular acceleration based on forces derived from a simple motor model. A loop overrun issue was encountered though some optimizations were implemented to address it efforts are still focused on reducing the load on the RoboRIO.

I looked through the CTRE documentation but couldn’t find information about physics and setpoint generation I’m curious if CTRE offers anything related to this Additionally I wonder if the code runs on the RoboRIO since if it does migrating to CTRE’s swerve system wouldn’t be necessary due to features like synchronization and latency compensation being customizable.

The AdvantageKit swerve template from 6328 includes a setpoint generator, allowing direct loading of config JSON via Tuner X. While this setup works effectively, if a more advanced solution is needed, alternative methods may be more suitable.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: We used a 254-level setpoint generator initially—it established various robot-relative constraints and monitored motor activity, generating motor setpoints. Recently, we switched to something that functions similarly yet operates in a field-relative manner, producing drivetrain setpoints. This new system simplifies operations considerably and avoids potential CPU issues. Afterward, we turned it off for competitions due to adequate driver control and an optimal center of gravity, minimizing concerns about tipping over.
